member_organisations: www.europo.eu  - The national Esperanto associations of all 28 EU Member States.  Natural persons are not members of EEU, only national Esperanto associations in EU Member States.
fields_of_interest: Culture and media, Culture, Education and training, Youth, Justice and Fundamental Rights, Research and innovation, External Relations, Communication
eu_initiatives:
1. Multilingualism and improved language learning 
 
2.  Strengthening of a common European identity in harmony with national and regional identities 
 
3. Recognition of the culture which Esperanto represents
subsection: Non-governmental organisations, platforms and networks and similar
membership: ECSPM/European Civil Society Platform for Multilingualism
goals__remit:
1.    The promotion of multilingualism and linguistic justice in Europe, by using the international language, Esperanto. 
2.    Sensitizing the EU institutions to the importance of language policy in bringing the citizen closer to European integration.  
3.    Coordinating the activities of the national Esperanto associations in all 28 EU Member States. 
4.    Promoting objective knowledge of Esperanto and the culture which it represents. Esperanto was formally recognized as a language of culture by Poland in November 2014, and by PEN International in 1993.
relevant_communication: EEU has implemented many EU-financed projects over many years, such as the lingvo-info project; the Trieste conference in 2012 on what would Europe be like today if the EU had never been founded; many international conferences on ways of bringing the citizen closer to European integration. Our most recent project is called "Language Accelerator". It aims to produce didactic material to improve language-learning based on the 250 most frequently-used morphemes in Esperanto, and may also be used by teachers who do not speak Esperanto.
